title: Emergency Response Preparedness in the UK
abstractText:
The project set out to bring together diverse groups of researchers interested in the broad area of emergency preparedness (from psychology, sociology, operations, IT systems, management) and link them with relevant practitioners in the field (emergency planning, responders, military, government). The ESRC funds were used to fund seminars at which existing academic studies were discussed and placed into the practitioner context.

Further seminars were focussed on particular practitioner issues and resulted in the establishment of closer links and understanding between academic researchers and emergency planners and responders. A major international conference was run as the last seminar which opened the membership of the seminar as well as shared research findings from a much broader range of perspectives and research traditions. Additionally, a world expert (Professor Bill Starbuck) was brought from the USA to explore the central problem of uncertainty and risk in crisis response.

The outcome was a well developed inter-disciplinary network which has already been successful in collaborating on:

  • securing three funded projects and developing two additional proposals
  • making a proposal to the International Standards Organisation between members of the seminar
  • members being invited to be keynote speakers as a result of the contacts made.
